sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying ring
message_1: Consider a circular ring of radius 10 cm carrying a current of 5 A. Determine the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the ring at a distance of 15 cm from the center of the ring.
message_2:
To determine the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the circular ring, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a current-carrying loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the ring, and x is the distance from the center of the ring.

Given values:
I = 5 A
R = 10 cm = 0.1 m
x = 15 cm = 0.15 m

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.15 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-6) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0225 m²)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-8) Tm) / (2 * (0.0325 m²)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-8) Tm) / (2 * 0.0187 m^(3/2))

B ≈ 3.36 × 10^(-6) T

So, the magnitude of the magnetic field at the given point is approximately 3.36 × 10^(-6) T.

As for the direction of the magnetic field, it follows the right-hand rule. If you curl the fingers of your right hand in the direction of the current (counterclockwise when looking from above), your thumb will point in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will be pointing upwards along the axis of the ring.
